facts.text: This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali, J. This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari. The app

facts.text: The appellant was one of the persons who had filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.

anchor.surface_text: ellant was one of the persons who had filed numberination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district. On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that companystituency

facts.text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that constituency took up for scrutiny the nomination papers filed by the various candidates.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that companystituency took up for scrutiny the numberination papers filed by the various candidates and on the same day he rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds

facts.text: On the same day he rejected the appellants nomination paper on certain grounds.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day he rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds which need number be set out as they are number material to the point raised in this appeal.

facts.text: The appellant thereupon moved the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon moved the High companyrt under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his numberination paper and to direct the Returning Officer to include his name

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The appellants contention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is not correct that the view expressed by the High Court is not affected by article 329(b) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is number companyrect that the view expressed by the High Court is number affected by article 329 b  of the Constitution and that he was entitled to a writ of certiorari

facts.text: The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have numberjurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of numberination papers. This view is in my opinion companyrect and must be affirmed. The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed.

facts.text: Besides the Madras High Court seven other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution to entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have numberjurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of numberination papers.

arguments.claim: Election in Part XV and Article 329(b) means entire process culminating in candidate declared elected (wide sense).

anchor.surface_text: As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning. In the narrow sense, it is used to mean the final selection of a candidate which may embrace the result of the poll when there is polling or a particular candidates being returned unopposed when there is no poll. In the wide sense the word is used to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected

arguments.claim: Questioning Returning Officer's rejection of nomination paper is calling election in question under Article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the main controversy in this appeal centers round the meaning of the words no election shall be called in question except by an election petition in article 329 b , and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Part XV of Constitution and Representation of the People Act, 1951 provides exclusive remedy of election petition; no intermediate challenge.

anchor.surface_text: I think it follows by necessary implication from the language of this provision that those grounds cannot be urged in any other manner, at any other stage and before any other court. If the grounds on which an election can be called in question could be raised at an earlier stage and errors, it any, are rectified, there will be no meaning in enacting a provision like article 329 b and in setting up a special tribunal.

arguments.claim: Where statute creates right/liability and special remedy, that remedy must be followed (Wolverhampton rule). Applies to election law.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well-recognized that where a right or liability is created by a statute which gives a special remedy for enforcing it, the remedy provided by that statute only must be availed of. This rule was stated with great clarity by Willes J. in Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford

arguments.claim: Sections 80, 100, 105, 170 RPA bar jurisdiction except election petition; mirrors Article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: Section 80, which is drafted in almost the same language as article 329 b , provides that no election shall be called in question except by an election petition presented in accordance with the provisions of this part. ... Section 170 provides that no civil court shall have jurisdiction to question the legality of any action taken or of any decision given by the Returning Officer

arguments.claim: English election law similar language excludes writs for nomination rejection; always by election petition.

anchor.surface_text: it has never been held in England that the improper rejection of a nomination paper can be the subject of a writ of certiorari or mandamus. On the other hand, it was conceded at the bar that the question of improper rejection of a nomination paper has always been brought up in that country before the appropriate tribunal by means of an election petition after the conclusion of the election.

arguments.claim: Elections must conclude early per time schedule; disputes postponed till after to avoid protraction (public interest over individual hardship).

anchor.surface_text: it does not require much argument to show that in a country with a democratic constitution in which the legislatures have to play a very important role, it will lead to serious consequences if the elections are unduly protracted or obstructed.

arguments.claim: Seven other State High Courts have held no jurisdiction under article 226 for improper rejection of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers.

arguments.claim: Special election tribunals' jurisdiction final and exclusive (Theberge v. Landry).

anchor.surface_text: the intention of the legislature to create a tribunal for the purpose of trying election petitions in a manner which should make its decision final for all purposes, and should not annex to it the incident of its judgment being reviewed by the Crown under its prerogative.

holdings.text: The view of the Madras High Court and seven other State High Courts that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution to entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers is correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers. This view is in my opinion correct and must be affirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 329(b) provides that no election shall be called in question except by election petition; rejection of nomination is part of election process covered by wide meaning of 'election'; exclusive remedy via petition, confirmed by RPA scheme and precedents.

holdings.text: The word 'election' in article 329(b) has been used in the wide sense to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning. In the narrow sense, it is used to mean the final selection of a candidate which may embrace the result of the poll when there is polling or a particular candidates being returned unopposed when there is no poll. In the wide sense the word is used to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long usage in democratic contexts, precedents like Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami, consistent with Part XV including 'conduct of elections' in Art 324.

holdings.text: Questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper is comprehended within the words 'no election shall be called in question' in article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the main controversy in this appeal centers round the meaning of the words no election shall be called in question except by an election petition in article 329 b , and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nomination scrutiny is a stage in the entire election process; challenging it interrupts scheme postponing disputes to post-election petition; s.100 RPA lists improper rejection as ground for voiding election.

holdings.text: The only remedy for improper rejection of nomination paper is by election petition after the election; no intermediate challenge under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: I think it follows by necessary implication from the language of this provision that those grounds cannot be urged in any other manner, at any other stage and before any other court. If the grounds on which an election can be called in question could be raised at an earlier stage and errors, it any, are rectified, there will be no meaning in enacting a provision like article 329 b and in setting up a special tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Part XV and RPA (ss.80,100,105,170) mandates exclusive post-election remedy; Wolverhampton rule applies to statutory rights with special remedies; public interest in timely elections outweighs individual hardship.

holdings.text: Section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is not ultra vires; Returning Officer has jurisdiction to scrutinize and reject nomination papers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scrutiny is a preliminary stage/duty before election completion, not 'questioning election'; does not usurp tribunal's role under Art 329(b).

holdings.text: The scheme of election law requires all disputes arising out of elections, including improper rejection of nominations, to be raised only by election petition before special tribunal after election, not by courts at intermediate stages.

anchor.surface_text: the intention of the legislature to create a tribunal for the purpose of trying election petitions in a manner which should make its decision final for all purposes, and should not annex to it the incident of its judgment being reviewed by the Crown under its prerogative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with English law, RPA provisions, Part XV; public interest in swift elections; Theberge v. Landry affirms finality of special election tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal is dismissed affirming the High Court's view on lack of jurisdiction under Article 329(b).

edges.explanation: Argument a12 invokes the Wolverhampton rule that where a statute creates a right/liability with a special remedy, that remedy must be followed, and applies it to election law, thereby grounding the concept c13 of election petition as the exclusive remedy.
Argument a12 on exclusive statutory remedies supports holding h1 denying Art. 226 jurisdiction in favor of election petitions.
Wolverhampton rule argument a12 that special election remedy must be followed supports holding h3 on scope of Art. 329(b).
Argument a17 on final and exclusive special tribunal jurisdiction supports concept c1 exclusion of Art 226 for election matters like nomination rejection

edges.explanation: Fact f1 of the petition for writ of certiorari being dismissed triggers the application of concept c12 on unavailability of such writ
Fact f2 of appellant filing nomination paper provides context triggering issue i1 on questioning its rejection under Art 329(b)

Holding h1 on lack of jurisdiction under Article 226 to entertain such petitions supports the concept c12 of writ of certiorari not being available

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers. This view is in my opinion correct and must be affirmed.
The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning. In the narrow sense, it is used to mean the final selection of a candidate which may embrace the result of the poll when there is polling or a particular candidates being returned unopposed when there is no poll. In the wide sense the word is used to connote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected
The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

Holding h3 that questioning the Returning Officer's rejection is covered by Article 329(b) supports the concept c12 that writ of certiorari is not available due to Article 329(b)

anchor.surface_text: Now, the main controversy in this appeal centers round the meaning of the words no election shall be called in question except by an election petition in article 329 b , and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question.
The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

I think it follows by necessary implication from the language of this provision that those grounds cannot be urged in any other manner, at any other stage and before any other court. If the grounds on which an election can be called in question could be raised at an earlier stage and errors, it any, are rectified, there will be no meaning in enacting a provision like article 329 b and in setting up a special tribunal.
The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.
